title: 109_s671
content: Credit for certain energy-efficient property. Credit for certain energy-efficient property is provided for energy-efficient building property, specifically a fuel cell power plant. This amendment expands the definition of energy property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment expands the definition of energy property to include a fuel cell power plant that generates electricity using an electrochemical process and generates at least 0.5 kilowatts. The credit for energy-efficient building property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to 30 percent of the property's basis. The amendment expands the definition of energy property to include a fuel cell power plant that converts fuel into electricity using electrochemical means. The credit for energy-efficient building property placed in service is limited to 30 percent of the property's basis. The energy percentage for energy-efficient building property is 30 percent, and for any other energy property, it is 10 percent. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new sections related to nonbusiness property and personal credits. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2004. "New section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property." The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a credit against the tax imposed for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. The credit is limited to 30 percent of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. This includes costs for energy-efficient property installed in a residence in the US, with labor costs included. The property must meet certain standards and have its original use with the taxpayer. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a credit for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures, applicable to property under section 48(a)(3). Special rules apply for jointly occupied dwelling units, where individuals are treated as one taxpayer for determining the credit allowable for expenditures made during the calendar year. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. Individuals in cooperative housing corporations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any corporation expenditures. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. Individuals in cooperative housing corporations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any corporation expenditures. In the case of an individual who is a member of a condominium management association with respect to a condominium which the individual owns, such individual shall be treated as having made his proportionate share of any expenditures of such association. The term 'condominium management association' means an organization that meets specific requirements with respect to a condominium project where most units are used as residences. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. Individuals in cooperative housing corporations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any corporation expenditures. In the case of an individual who is a member of a condominium management association with respect to a condominium which the individual owns, such individual shall be treated as having made his proportionate share of any expenditures of such association. The term 'condominium management association' means an organization that meets specific requirements with respect to a condominium project where most units are used as residences. Allocation of expenditures for nonbusiness purposes is based on the percentage of use, and expenditures are considered made upon completion of installation or construction. The expenditure for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property shall be treated as made when the taxpayer begins using the structure. The amount of the expenditure is the cost incurred. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not considered for determining nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures. Basis adjustments reduce the increase in property basis resulting from the expenditure if a credit is allowed. The section applies to expenditures made before December 31, 2009, and any credit allowed will reduce the resulting expenditure. Conforming amendments are made to section 1016 of the Code to account for the credit allowed under section 25C. The new item is inserted after section 25B, with conforming amendments made to section 1016 of the Code for the credit allowed under section 25C. The amendments made by this subsection apply to expenditures for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property made after December 31, 2004.
